[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/encoding_type.rs] [Function: load_key()] [Symlink attack] Does load_key() validate that the path is not a symlink to a sensitive file, or can attackers use symlinks to load system keys or read arbitrary files? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/encoding_type.rs] [Function: load_key()] [TOCTOU race condition] Is there a race condition between read_from_file() and subsequent key validation where an attacker can swap the file contents, loading a different key than was validated? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/encoding_type.rs] [Function: load_key()] [File size validation] Does load_key() validate file size before reading, or can attackers provide gigabyte-sized key files that exhaust memory and crash validator nodes? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/encoding_type.rs] [Function: load_key()] [Error information leakage] When load_key() fails, does the error message expose sensitive filesystem paths or key material that could aid attackers in compromising validators? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/encoding_type.rs] [Function: load_key()] [Concurrent access] Can multiple threads calling load_key() on the same file cause race conditions or inconsistent key loading across validator subsystems? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/encoding_type.rs] [Function: read_from_file()] [Path injection] Can the path.display() formatting in error messages be exploited to inject malicious strings into logs or monitoring systems? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/encoding_type.rs] [Function: read_from_file()] [File descriptor leak] Does read_from_file() properly close file descriptors on error, or can repeated failed reads exhaust file descriptors and cause validator crashes? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-core/src/encoding_type.rs] [Function: read_from_file()] [Permission validation] Does read_from_file() verify file permissions before reading, or can attackers trick validators into reading world-readable key files that should be protected? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/encoding_type.rs] [Function: read_from_file()] [Memory exhaustion] Can attackers create special files (e.g., /dev/zero, named pipes) that cause std::fs::read() to allocate infinite memory and crash validators? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/encoding_type.rs] [Function: read_from_file()] [Error string allocation] Can extremely long file paths cause the error message string formatting to allocate excessive memory during error handling? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/encoding_type.rs] [Type: EncodingType] [Default encoding] Is the #[default] attribute on Hex encoding secure, or can default initialization cause keys to be encoded in a less secure format than intended? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/encoding_type.rs] [Type: EncodingType] [Format downgrade] Can attackers force encoding type selection to downgrade from BCS to Hex/Base64, exploiting differences in validation strictness between formats? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/encoding_type.rs] [Type: EncodingType] [Format confusion] Can inconsistent EncodingType values across validators cause them to decode the same byte stream as different keys, breaking consensus? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/encoding_type.rs] [Function: from_str()] [Case sensitivity bypass] Does the to_lowercase() normalization in from_str() create security issues if encoding type selection can be manipulated through case variations? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/encoding_type.rs] [Function: from_str()] [Unicode normalization] Can attackers use Unicode lookalike characters to bypass from_str() validation and specify invalid encoding types? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/encoding_type.rs] [Function: from_str()] [Whitespace in encoding type] Does from_str() trim whitespace from the input string, or can leading/trailing spaces cause encoding type selection to fail in configuration files? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/encoding_type.rs] [Type: EncodingError] [Error message injection] Can attackers craft inputs that inject malicious content into EncodingError messages, exploiting log injection vulnerabilities in monitoring systems? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/encoding_type.rs] [Type: EncodingError] [Sensitive data in errors] Do error messages from BCS, UnableToParse, or UTF8 variants leak sensitive key material or cryptographic parameters? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/encoding_type.rs] [Type: EncodingError] [Error correlation] Can timing or error message differences between encoding types be exploited to infer information about key formats or contents through side channels? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/encoding_type.rs] [Trait: From<FromUtf8Error>] [Error conversion information loss] Does the UTF8 error conversion preserve all security-relevant error information, or is data lost that could prevent proper error handling? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/encoding_type.rs] [Function: decode_key()] [Format detection bypass] Can attackers craft byte sequences that are valid in multiple encoding formats (BCS, Hex, Base64) but decode to different keys, causing validator inconsistencies? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/encoding_type.rs] [Function: encode_key() + decode_key()] [Roundtrip inconsistency] Is encode_key() followed by decode_key() guaranteed to produce identical keys for all formats, or can encoding/decoding asymmetries break key consistency? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/encoding_type.rs] [All functions] [Encoding canonicalization] Can different byte representations encode to the same string (or vice versa), enabling attackers to create key collisions that break signature uniqueness? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/encoding_type.rs] [Function: decode_key()] [Trait validation bypass] Can decode_key() bypass ValidCryptoMaterial trait constraints through unsafe deserialization, allowing invalid keys to be loaded into the system? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/encoding_type.rs] [Function: encode_key()] [Trait assumption violation] Does encode_key() assume ValidCryptoMaterial::to_bytes() always succeeds, or can panics in to_bytes() crash validators during key serialization? (High)
